newsitem.title: GERMANY: Industry slams German TV network's ad-free night.
newsitem.headline: Industry slams German TV network's ad-free night.

text.p: Media and advertising industry representatives have blasted private television station Sat1 for staging a sponsored evening of programming without advertising, calling it a threat to the industry.

Although innovation in advertising is necessary, it is a mistake to suggest to viewers they can have television without ads, Hans Kratz, the chairman of the German Organisation of Advertising Media (OWM), said on Wednesday.
"There are other ways to make oneself stand out that do not harm companies that advertise," Kratz said. "This is absolutely the wrong way to go."

"The concept is curious, downright absurd," said Helmut Thoma, the general manager of rival private network RTL, which on Thursday posted 3.2 billion marks in ad sales for 1996. "RTL would certainly not broadcast such a night of programming."

Sat1 hailed its experiment with ad-free programming on Saturday evening a success, saying it had pulled in a 19.2 percent market share among viewers above the age of three, five points above its nearest competitor, public station ARD.
"This event had a public relations effect," Sat1 marketing director Klaus-Peter Schulz said. "We see it as our job to create the widest possible offering in the advertising-driven industry."
Brewer Kulmbacher Reichel Braeu AG sponsored the evening, the first of four scheduled "Kulmbacher Film Nights", which featured three hit Hollywood films.
